Award.AwardTitle: Bridging the Gap between Theory and Next-generation Observations of the First Galaxies and Quasars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will develop improved simulation tools for computations that will help us understand the formation of the first galaxies and quasars. A number of upcoming observatories will provide data addressing a crucial epoch in cosmic history: the Epoch of Reionization (EOR), when the first galaxies and quasars lit up the dark ages and reionized the neutral hydrogen gas. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. Dr. Li will create a new program, Research Experience in Astronomy and Computation for High-school teachers (REACH), for a week-long Penn State In-Service Workshop in Astronomy. REACH will provide high-school educators interdisciplinary education and training in astronomy and computer science

Dr. Li will undertake a comprehensive approach to bridging theory and observations of the EOR by combining multi-scale cosmological hydrodynamic simulations with multi-wavelength radiative transfer calculations. Three main goals are pursued in this project: First, she will perform simulations on both galactic and cosmological scales to follow the formation and evolution of early galaxies and quasars. Second, she will perform post-processing radiative transfer calculations to derive multi-wavelength properties of galaxies and map the reionization history. Third, she will confront models with observations to understand the physical processes, and make predictions for future surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to bridge theories and observations of  the epoch of reionization  by combining multi-scale cosmological hydrodynamic simulations with multi-wavelength radiative transfer calcula- tions. Three main goals are pursued in this project: First, we will perform simulations on both galactic and cosmological scales to follow the formation and evolution of early galaxies and quasars. Second, we will perform post-processing radiative transfer calculations to derive multi-wavelength properties of galaxies and map the reionization history. Third, we will confront models with observations to understand the physical processes, and make predictions for future surveys.

We have accomplished the following objectives during the course of this project:

  1. Training of undergraduate student Yiting Li, who graduated from Penn State in summer 2018 and was accepted by a number of prestigious graduate programs. She is now a graduate student at UC Santa Barbara.
  2. Training of graduate student Moupiy Maji, who obtained her PhD from Penn State this summer, and is now a postdoc researcher at the University of Geneva.
  3. Training of postdoc Qirong Zhu, who received the prestigeous McWilliams Postdoctoral Fellowship in Cosmology and is now a research fellow at the McWilliams Cosmology Center at Carnegie Mellon University.
  4. Training of scores of high-school science teachers from Pennsylvania and nearby states through the Penn State In-Service Workshop in Astronomy from 2015 to 2019.
  5. The development and improvement of the parallel, 3-D multi-wavelength radiative transfer code ART^2. This comprehensive code includes continuum from x-ray to sub-millimeter, resonant scattering Lyman_alpha and molecular lines (such as CO), as well as far-infrared fine structure lines (such as CII, OIII, and NII). These features are extremely useful in studying multi-band properties of galaxies at different redshift. This version has been used /tested by a number of collaborators. We will make it available to the scientific community.
  6. The publication of 20 papers in major astronomy and astrophysics journals, and 5 papers in preparation.
  7. The results from this project have been disseminated through papers, conferences, seminars, and outreach events such as the AstroFest at Penn State in the summer, which typically draws thousands of visitors.
  8. Some of the results was reported in scientific news media around the world including the CfA News and the phys.org.
